ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved my oral speaking skills, writing, and Spanish comprehension.
More insights into spanish art and culture, and more proficiency in the spanish language
conversational spanish skills; reading longer length texts; learning spanish culture and history
I learned alot about magical realism within Spanish artwork.
Intermediate Spanish, Comprehension of  non-textbook Spanish sources
Spanish language and grammar.
I developed no knowledge, skills, or insights by taking this course. At most, I became a slightly better public speaker. However, that would honestly be a stretch. This was a waste of a Yale class.
I learned more grammar.
Intermediate spanish practice.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The in-class exercises for this class were not very helpful in keeping me engaged and excited about the material.
Possibly too much focus on the arts and culture side of the language compared to the language itself
Provide aid for paying for course materials and superset
I think that it was very interactive and I like how the professor would consistently check our writing in class, but classes were a bit dull at times.
course allows you to enjoy learning the language, but is not very grammar orientated
This was a great course! One strength was that there are many projects and assignments which I found helpful for learning.

This course could only be improved - it was the worst course I have taken in years. Everyday we completed a worksheet which taught us nothing and could not have been less interesting. Everyday could have been asynchronous. Professor Glenski never taught us one skill, we simply filled out the sheet as a class and would leave. It was truly a waste of 50 minutes.
I learned more grammar, but I still think it could be taught in a better way. I felt like I needed a lot more practice.

The entire course is centered on review and practice of grammar and language structure we learn in L2 spanish. It would be nice to have a more in-depth curriculum for the L3 class. Much of the work felt like busy work for this reason.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This class is not very difficult, but it is also not incredibly exciting. Take it for a relatively easy language requirement but nothing more.
I would, for those who need language credits or wish to improve their spanish
Yes because its great for learning about Spanish culture and art.
yes, excellent teacher and material
Yes! This is a great course to keep learning Spanish and not too stressful.

I would never tell a student to take this course, at least not with Sarah Glenski. It was the worst class I have taken in a decade and while I believe Spanish 130 could be a good class, it certainly cannot if Sarah Glenski is the professor. It was incredibly boring, taught students nothing, and was graded extremely harshly.
I wouldn't recommend it because I honestly didn't learn a whole lot, but I think that was because my level of Spanish was a lot higher than what the course was teaching.
If you want to learn spanish, then, of course!
